title: Contributing to fellingdateR
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to fellingdateR
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to fellingdateR
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("hanecakr/fellingDateR", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to fellingdateR
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to fellingdateR
text: Please note fellingdateR project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

what: fellingdateR: Estimate, report and combine felling dates of historical tree-ring series
title: Get started with `fellingdateR`
text: R-package offers set functions can assist infer felling date estimates dated tree-ring series. presence (partially) preserved sapwood waney edge allows estimate range actual felling date, individual series well group timbers. Furthermore, additional function provides tool sum sapwood probability distributions, comparable ‘summed probability densities’ commonly applied sets radiocarbon (14C) dates. can assumed group historical timbers felled time (.e. year), due absence bark/cambial zone (waney edge) last formed tree ring assessed, preserved sapwood rings can used infer date range felling date. Taking account observed number sapwood rings samples combining single estimate, likely provide accurate precise estimate felling date year group timbers study. vignette provides quick overview package main functions.

previous_headings: fellingdateR: Estimate, report and combine felling dates of historical tree-ring series > Main functions
title: Get started with `fellingdateR`
text: function computes probability density function (PDF) highest probability density interval (hdi) felling date range based observed number sapwood rings, chronological dating selected sapwood data model. example , 10 sapwood rings observed sample (last ring dated 1234 AD) supposed provenance Southern Baltic region (sapwood model published Wazny, 1990. hdi delineates interval actual felling date likely situated. shortest interval within probability distribution given probability mass credible interval. hdi summarizes distribution specifying interval spans distribution, say 95% , every point inside interval higher credibility point outside interval. hdi = FALSE matrix returned scaled p values number observed sapwood rings. results procedure can visualized setting plot = TRUE.
code: sw_interval(n_sapwood = 10,             last = 1234,             hdi = TRUE,             cred_mass = .95,              sw_data = "Wazny_1990",              densfun = "lognormal") #>   lower upper         p #> 1  1234  1250 0.9611793 # 10 sapwood rings observed and the Wazny 1990 sapwood model: sw_interval(n_sapwood = 10,             last = 1234,             hdi = TRUE,             cred_mass = .95,              sw_data = "Wazny_1990",              densfun = "lognormal",             plot = TRUE)

text: read_fh() function extension dplR::read.fh() function dplR package (Bunn 2008, Bunn 2010, Bunn et al. 2022). allows read .fh (format Heidelberg) files ring widths additional information found HEADER fields listed attributes. function also works ring-width data CHRONO HALF-CHRONO format. Furthermore, read_fh() function case insensitive. example , .fh file dated tree-ring series medieval ship DOEL1 read read_fh(). ring width measurement, different formats, converted data.frame. header = TRUE, get_header() function triggered HEADER fields .fh file returned data.frame, instead ring-width measurements. data.frame HEADER fields can used input sw_functions:  attempt combine dated tree-ring series DOEL1 single felling-date range fails. tree-ring series represent single event. previous_headings: fellingdateR: Estimate, report and combine felling dates of historical tree-ring series > Helper functions
title: Get started with `fellingdateR`
text: cor_table() function computes common correlation values dated tree-ring series (x) set reference chronologies (y). function assists checking end date series absolutely dated reference chronologies, also select appropriate sapwood model data according provenance wood (running chronologies represent geographically confined region). correlation values computed : glk: ‘Gleichläufigkeit’ ‘percentage parallel variation’ (Buras & Wilmking 2015; Eckstein & Bauch 1969; Huber 1943; Visser 2020) glk_p: significance level associated glk-value (Jansma 1995) r_pearson: Pearson’s correlation coefficient t_St: Student’s t-value t_BP: t-values according Baillie & Pilcher (1973) algorithm t_Ho: t-values according Hollstein (1980) algorithm

what: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: function calculates common correlation values dated tree-ring series (x) set reference chronologies (y). master chronologies provided, series x compared series x. values reported pairs series common overlap >= min_overlap. correlation values computed include: glk: 'Gleichläufigkeit' 'percentage parallel variation' (Buras & Wilmking 2015; Eckstein & Bauch 1969; Huber 1942; Visser 2020) glk_p: significance level associated glk-value (Jansma 1995) r_pearson: Pearson's correlation coefficient t_St: Student's t-value t_BP: t-values according Baillie & Pilcher (1973) algorithm t_Ho: t-values according Hollstein (1980) algorithm

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
code: cor_table(   x,   y = NULL,   min_overlap = 50,   remove_duplicates = TRUE,   output = "table",   sort_by = "t_Ho" )

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: x data.frame class ´rwl' tree-ring data. column represents measurement series, row names correspond (calendar) years. y data.frame class 'rwl' tree-ring data. column represents measurement series chronology, row names correspond (calendar) years. NULL (default), x compared (y = x). min_overlap numeric value specifying minimum overlap required series correlation calculation. remove_duplicates logical value. TRUE, identical pairs series references removed output. output desired output format, either "matrix" "table" (default). sort_by correlation value output sorted series x. One "r_pearson", "t_St", "glk", "glk_p", "t_BP", "t_Ho". Default "t_Ho"

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: function returns list correlation matrices output set "matrix." output set "table," returns data.frame reporting correlation values.

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: function computes various correlation values tree-ring series data.frame x set reference chronologies data.frame y. y provided, compares series x series `x.

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
text: Baillie, M.G.L., Pilcher, J.R. (1973) simple crossdating program tree-ring research. Tree-Ring Bulletin 33, 7–14. http://hdl.handle.net/10150/260029 Buras, . Wilmking, M. (2015) Correcting calculation Gleichläufigkeit, Dendrochronologia 34, 29-30. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dendro.2015.03.003 Eckstein, D. Bauch, J. (1969) Beitrag zur Rationalisierung eines dendrochronologischen Verfahrens und zur Analyse seiner Aussagesicherheit. Forstwissenschaftliches Centralblatt, 88(1), 230-250. Huber, B. (1943) Über die Sicherheit jahrringchronologischer Datierung. Holz als Roh- und Werkstoff 6, 263-268. https://doi.org/10.1007/BF02603303 Hollstein E. (1980) Mitteleuropäische Eichenchronologie. Trierer dendrochronologische Forschungen zur Archäologie und Kunstgeschichte, Trierer Grabungen und Forschungen 11, Mainz Rhein. Jansma, E. (1995) RemembeRINGs; development application local regional tree-ring chronologies oak purposes archaeological historical research Netherlands, Nederlandse Archeologische Rapporten 19, Rijksdienst voor het Oudheidkundig Bodemonderzoek, Amersfoort. https://dspace.library.uu.nl/handle/1874/45149 Schweingruber, F. H. (1988) Tree rings: basics applications dendrochronology, Kluwer Academic Publishers, Dordrecht, Netherlands, 276 p. Visser, R.M. (2020) similarity tree-ring patterns: Assessing influence semi-synchronous growth changes Gleichläufigkeit big tree-ring data sets, Archaeometry 63, 204-215. https://doi.org/10.1111/arcm.12600

title: Calculate correlation values between tree-ring series — cor_table
code: # example code  Doel1 <- system.file("extdata", "DOEL1.fh", package = "fellingdateR") Doel1_trs <- read_fh(Doel1, verbose = FALSE) # crossdating ring-width series from Doel 1 against each other:  cor_results <- cor_table(Doel1_trs, output = "table", min_overlap = 80)

what: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
text: function reports felling date estimate individual tree-ring series, based presence/absence sapwood /waney edge. three possible modes reporting: terminus post quem earliest possible felling date: heartwood rings observed measured felling date range interval: sapwood rings recorded, bark waney edge present. exact felling date: bark waney edge present measured sample. Reports lower upper boundaries felling date range individual tree-ring series.

title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
code: fd_report(   x,   series = "series",   last = "last",   n_sapwood = "n_sapwood",   waneyedge = "waneyedge",   sw_data = "Hollstein_1980",   cred_mass = 0.954,   densfun = "lognormal" )

title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
text: x Name data.frame least four columms, providing information id's tree-ring series number sapwood rings observed presence waney edge date assigned last measured ring. column describing sapwood data set used modelling computation hdi can provided well. series Name column x id's tree-ring series listed character values. last Name column x lists calendar year assigned last measured ring (numeric vector). n_sapwood Name column x number observed sapwood rings listed (numeric vector). waneyedge Name column x indicating presence (TRUE)/absence (FALSE) waney edge (logical vector). sw_data two options: character string providing name sapwood data set use modelling. one data sets listed sw_data_overview(), name data.frame sapwood data columns n_sapwood count, name column xthat lists series one sapwood data sets given sw_data_overview(). cred_mass scalar [0, 1] specifying mass within credible interval (default = .954). densfun Name density function fitted sapwood data set. one : lognormal (default value), normal, weibull, gammma.

title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
text: data.frame reporting estimate felling date tree-ring series?

title: Report felling dates of individual tree-ring series — fd_report
code: tmp <- data.frame(id = c("aaa", "bbb", "ccc"),                   swr = c(10, 11, 12),                   waneyedge = c(FALSE, FALSE,TRUE),                   end = c(10, 0, -10)) fd_report(tmp,           series = "id",           n_sapwood = "swr",           last = "end",           sw_data = "Wazny_1990") #>   series last n_sapwood waneyedge lower upper      felling_date sapwood_model #> 1    aaa   10        10     FALSE    10    26 between 10 and 26    Wazny_1990 #> 2    bbb    0        11     FALSE     0    15  between 0 and 15    Wazny_1990 #> 3    ccc  -10        12      TRUE    NA   -10            in -10    Wazny_1990  # Example with different sw_model for individual series  sw_models_for_indiv_series <- c("Sohar_2012_ELL_c",                                 "Wazny_1990",                                 "Hollstein_1980",                                 "vanDaalen_Norway",                                 "vanDaalen_Norway")  trs_example2_edit <- cbind(trs_example2, "sw_models" = sw_models_for_indiv_series)  fd_report(trs_example2_edit,           sw_data = "sw_models"           ) #>   series last n_sapwood waneyedge lower upper          felling_date #> 1 trs_06 1000         5     FALSE  1002  1013 between 1002 and 1013 #> 2 trs_07 1005        10     FALSE  1005  1021 between 1005 and 1021 #> 3 trs_08 1008        NA     FALSE  1014    NA            after 1014 #> 4 trs_09 1000         1     FALSE  1009  1031 between 1009 and 1031 #> 5 trs_10 1010        15      TRUE    NA  1010               in 1010 #>      sapwood_model #> 1 Sohar_2012_ELL_c #> 2       Wazny_1990 #> 3   Hollstein_1980 #> 4 vanDaalen_Norway #> 5 vanDaalen_Norway

what: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
text: function returns matrix 'upper' 'lower' limits hdi (highest density interval), associated probability 'p'. function first sorts input data.frame - columns 'n_sapwood´ 'p' (associated probability) - column 'p' decreasing order calculates HDI finding first value sorted probabilities higher specified cred_mass. finds indices values greater equal threshold, uses indices find 'upper' 'lower' limits hdi. function also calculates probability interval. final result returned matrix 'lower', 'upper', 'p' values. function applied functions sw_model sw_interval.

title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
code: hdi(x, a = "n_sapwood", b = "p", cred_mass = 0.954)

title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
text: x data.frame columns ´n_sapwood´ 'p' (associated probability). x computed functions sw_model, sw_interval, sw_combine. name column x lists number sapwood rings. b name column x lists associated probability n sapwood rings. cred_mass scalar [0, 1] specifying mass within credible interval (default = .954).

title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
text: matrix ´upper´ ´lower´ limits hdi, associated probability ´p´.

title: Compute the highest posterior density interval (hdi) — hdi
code: tmp <- data.frame(n_sapwood = seq(1,30, 1),                   p = dnorm(seq(1,30, 1), 15, 5)) hdi(tmp, cred_mass = 0.954) #>   lower upper         p #> 1     5    25 0.9645785

code: mov_av(x, w = 11, align = "center", edges = "fill")

title: Compute a running mean on a time series — mov_av
text: x numeric vector length(x), time series data. w width moving average window. wis even, one value future included. align alignment window relative current data point. can one : align = "center": average assigned center window (default). align = "left": average includes current value next (w-1) values. align = "right": average includes current value previous (w-1) values. edges Defines values computed start end series. Options : edges = "fill": average calculated decreasing number values near edges vector (default). edges = "nofill": result includes NA values window cover w values.

what: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: function reads Heidelberg format file (.fh) containing ring width data returns HEADER fields attributes data.frame´measurement data. Heidelberg file format described detail : https://www.treeringsociety.org/resources/SOM/Brewer_Murphy_SupplementaryMaterial.pdf

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
code: read_fh(fname, BC_correction = FALSE, verbose = TRUE, header = FALSE)

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: fname character vector specifying name .fh file read. BC_correction logical. TRUE correction moves BC-dates one year forward. verbose logical. FALSE, messages suppressed reading process. header logical. TRUE HEADER fields returned data.frame; FALSE, measurement data returned.

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: header TRUE, data.frame returned HEADER fields attributes. header FALSE, data.frame class rwl ring-width measurements columns returned, (calendar) years row names.`

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: function reads .fh file ring width data either block (decadal format) column format (e.g., comment flags) used TSAP program. function also capable reading chronologies half-chronos decadal format. read_fh function case-insensitive. Information found HEADER fields listed attributes data.frame´measurement data. . header fields harvested .fh file include: "Project", "FirstMeasurementDate", "Location", "Town", "Street", "Client", "Longitude", "Latitude", "DateOfSampling", "FirstMeasurementDate", "SapWoodRings", "Comment", "MissingRingsAfter", "InvalidRingsAfter", "MissingringsBefore", "DeltaMissingringsBefore", "ChronoMemberKeycodes", "PersId"

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: function extension read.fh() dplR package (https://github.com/opendendro/dplR), developed maintained Prof. dr. Andy Bunn (Bunn 2008, Bunn 2010, Bunn et al. 2022) https://opendendro.org/.

title: Read a Heidelberg format (.fh) tree-ring file — read_fh
text: original read.fh() function part dplR package (https://github.com/opendendro/dplR) developed Christian Zang, new features patches contributed Mikko Korpela Ronald Visser. read_fh() function expands functionalities original dplR::read.fh().

what: Compute a single felling date range by combining multiple sapwood estimates — sw_combine
title: Compute a single felling date range by combining multiple sapwood estimates — sw_combine
text: function assesses whether possible combine multiple sapwood estimates single felling date range.

title: Compute a single felling date range by combining multiple sapwood estimates — sw_combine
code: sw_combine(   x,   series = "series",   last = "last",   n_sapwood = "n_sapwood",   waneyedge = "waneyedge",   sw_data = "Hollstein_1980",   densfun = "lognormal",   cred_mass = 0.954,   hdi = TRUE,   plot = FALSE )

title: Compute a single felling date range by combining multiple sapwood estimates — sw_combine
text: x data.frame least four columns, providing information ID's tree-ring series, number sapwood rings observed, presence waney edge calendar date assigned last measured ring. column describing sapwood data set used modelling computation hdi can provided well. series Name column x ID's tree-ring series listed character values. last Name column x calendar years assigned last measured ring listed (numeric). n_sapwood Name column x number observed sapwood rings listed (numeric). waneyedge Name column x indicating presence (TRUE)/absence (FALSE) waney edge (logical vector). sw_data name sapwood data set use modelling. one data sets listed sw_data_overview(), name data.frame sapwood data columns n_sapwood count. densfun Name density function fitted sapwood data set. one : lognormal (default value), normal, weibull, gammma. cred_mass scalar [0, 1] specifying mass within credible interval (default = .954). hdi logical parameter. TRUE, lower upper limit highest density interval (credible interval) given combined felling date. FALSE, matrix returned scaled p values calendar years covering combined estimate felling date range. plot logical parameter. TRUE ggplot-plot style graph returned individual combined estimate felling date. FALSE, list numeric output modelling process returned.

title: Compute a single felling date range by combining multiple sapwood estimates — sw_combine
text: Depends value plot. TRUE ggplot-style returned, FALSE list combined probability ($raw_data$comb), modelling parameters ($sapwood_data, $sapwood_model, $cred_mass), Highest Posterior Density Interval combined combined felling date interval ($hdi_combine), Agreement indices model ($A_model) individual series ($individual_series$agr_index).

title: Compute a single felling date range by combining multiple sapwood estimates — sw_combine

TRUE, ggplot-style graph returned individual sapwood model estimate felling date range. FALSE, list numeric output modelling process returned.

title: Computes the limits of the felling date range — sw_interval

text: x data.frame columns c("series", "swr", "waneyedge" , "last"), Column "sw_model" optional. output read_fh(x, header = TRUE) series Name column x ID's tree-ring series listed character values. last Name column x calendar years assigned last measured ring listed (numeric). n_sapwood Name column x number observed sapwood rings listed (numeric) waneyedge Name column x indicating presence (TRUE)/absence (FALSE) waney edge (logical). sw_data name sapwood data set use modelling. one data sets listed sw_data_overview(), name data.frame sapwood data columns n_sapwood count. densfun Name density function fitted sapwood data set. one : lognormal (default value), normal, weibull, gammma. cred_mass scalar [0, 1] specifying mass within credible interval (default = .954). plot logical. TRUE, sw_sum_plot() triggered ggplot-style graph returned summed probability density (SPD). FALSE, list numeric output modelling process returned. scale_p logical. TRUE summed probability density scaled 1 (default).
